summary: Walter Lloyd was an individual working within the Office of General Counsel at the CIA. The documents suggest his involvement in handling legal matters related to CIA cases. Specifically, he was involved in Privacy Act case 71-728 concerning Werbell, as indicated by a speed letter estimating a completion date for the case. He was also a recipient of a document related to WerBell, as evidenced by an internal CIA routing slip. The documents suggest that Walter Lloyd's role was primarily administrative and legal, dealing with the processing and handling of information related to individuals of interest to the CIA.
significance: Based on the provided documents, Walter Lloyd's significance in the JFK context is not directly apparent. His role seems to be related to legal and administrative tasks within the CIA, specifically concerning Privacy Act cases and the handling of information related to individuals like Werbell. Without further information, it is difficult to ascertain any direct connection to the JFK assassination.
